questions.text: Which of the following animals serves as the most common mixing vessel for the emergence of new influenza virus strains ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Pigs serve as the most common mixing vessel for the emergence of new influenza virus strains.
  • The three influenza types show distinct epidemiologic behavior: type C causes only mild, isolated respiratory illness and doesn't lead to epidemics; type B can occasionally trigger outbreaks, but it is type A that is responsible for widespread, global pandemics.
  • Genetic studies of influenza A viruses from various regions support the idea that all mammalian influenza strains originate from an avian source.
  • Among the 18 hemagglutinin (HA) subtypes found in birds, only a few have crossed into mammals. For example, H1, H2, H3, H5, H7, and H9 are seen in humans, H1, H2, and H3 in pigs, and H3, H7 in horses.
  • Similarly, only 2 of the 11 neuraminidase (NA) subtypes found in birds, N1 and N2, occur in humans.
  • Avian influenza shows a wide clinical spectrum, from no symptoms to fatal disease in poultry like chickens and turkeys. In contrast, ducks often carry the virus without illness. In ducks, the virus replicates in intestinal cells and is excreted in feces into water, where it can remain infectious for long periods, especially at cooler temperatures.
  • This suggests avian influenza may be transmitted via water, spreading from wild birds to domestic animals such as pigs.
  • All known human pandemic influenza strains have arisen from genetic mixing (reassortment) between animal and human influenza viruses.
  • Research indicates that pigs act as hosts for this reassortment because they have cellular receptors for both avian and human influenza strains.
  • In terms of transmission, school-aged children are key carriers, with crowded school environments promoting airborne spread and facilitating household introduction of the virus.

Explanation of other options:

Birds (Option A): Birds (especially aquatic birds) are the primary reservoir of influenza A viruses. However, birds alone are not the usual mixing vessel; reassortment requires a host like pigs that can be infected by both bird and human strains.

Humans (Option B): Humans can be infected by influenza but generally lack dual receptor types to efficiently allow reassortment. Thus, they are not the major mixing vessel.

choices.text: -ve sense ssRNA with 8 segments and helical symmetry
-ve sense ssRNA with 10 segments and helical symmetry
+ve sense ssRNA with 8 segments and helical symmetry
+ve sense ssRNA with 10 segments and icosahedral symmetry

questions.text: Which of the following statements correctly describes the key characteristics of viruses in the Orthomyxoviridae family?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Orthomyxoviruses are medium-sized, enveloped viruses displaying helical symmetry.
  • These viruses may appear spherical or filamentous and possess surface projections that carry either hemagglutinin (HA) or neuraminidase (NA) activity.
  • Hemagglutinin facilitates viral entry by binding to sialic acid on host cells, while neuraminidase assists in the release of virions by cleaving sialic acid from cell surfaces and viral glycoproteins.

The structure of influenza virus is as shown below.

  • Their genome consists of linear, segmented, negative-sense, single-stranded RNA.
  • Virus maturation occurs through budding at the host cell membrane.
  • Orthomyxoviruses primarily include influenza viruses that infect humans and animals.
  • The segmented nature of their genome facilitates genetic reassortment when two strains infect the same cell, promoting high variability. This reassortment, along with interspecies transmission, is considered a key mechanism behind the emergence of novel pandemic influenza A strains in humans.
  • Antigenic variation in HA and NA occurs through antigenic drift (minor mutations accumulating over time) and antigenic shift (major changes due to reassortment between different strains, often across species), the latter being responsible for pandemics. Drift requires multiple mutations to become epidemiologically significant.
  • Influenza replication is rapid: host cell protein synthesis is halted by 3 hours post-infection, and new virions are released by 8-10 hours.
  • Replication begins with HA-mediated attachment to sialic acid, followed by endocytosis and uncoating aided by low pH and M2 protein ion channels.
  • Transcription occurs in the nucleus, where viral polymerase uses capped host primers to initiate synthesis. The virus produces monocistronic mRNAs for translation in the cytoplasm, and some segments undergo splicing.
  • RNA replication involves creating complementary positive strands that serve as templates for genomic RNA.
  • Maturation involves assembly of viral components, including HA and NA, followed by budding at the plasma membrane.
  • M1 protein anchors the nucleocapsid to the membrane. HA is cleaved during this process, and NA removes sialic acids, aiding virion release.

The lifecycle of influenza virus is illustrated below.

questions.text: A 1-year old girl presented to the Pediatric OPD with respiratory distress. On examination, she was found to have inspiratory stridor, barking cough, and hoarseness. Which organism is most commonly responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical vignette of inspiratory stridor, barking cough, and hoarseness is suggestive of croup which is caused by parainfluenza virus.
  • Croup, or laryngotracheobronchitis, is the most frequent cause of acute upper airway obstruction in children, typically due to parainfluenza virus infection of the glottic and subglottic regions.
  • The condition often begins with upper respiratory symptoms such as runny nose, sore throat, low-grade fever, and cough lasting 1-3 days.
  • As the disease progresses, affected children develop a barking cough, hoarseness, and inspiratory stridor.
  • Fever is often mild but may occasionally be as high as 39 - 40°C. Some children remain afebrile.
  • Symptoms usually worsen at night, sometimes recurring with diminishing severity over a few days, and resolve within a week. Agitation and crying worsen the symptoms, and children often prefer to sit upright.
  • The severity of airway obstruction varies, and in rare cases, it can worsen significantly, marked by rapid breathing, nasal flaring, retractions, and continuous stridor.
  • Croup is generally diagnosed clinically. Neck radiographs may show the characteristic "steeple sign," indicating subglottic narrowing as shown below though its absence doesn't rule out the diagnosis.

Explanation of other options:

Haemophilus influenza (Option A): Haemophilus influenzae a leading cause of bacterial otitis media, sinusitis, and, in patients with impaired mucociliary clearance, lower respiratory tract infections like bronchitis and pneumonia. Invasive disease can result in meningitis, especially in children aged 5 months to 5 years (before the conjugate vaccine), and may also present as septic arthritis or epiglottitis requiring emergency airway intervention. Barking cough and inspiratory stridor is more characteristic of croup.

Mumps (Option C): Mumps often presents with swelling of the salivary glands, especially the parotids, in about half of symptomatic cases, while a significant number remain subclinical. Central nervous system involvement, including aseptic meningitis and, less commonly, encephalitis, can occur typically without parotid swelling. After puberty, orchitis affects 20-50% of infected males and may lead to testicular atrophy, while oophoritis and pancreatitis are less common complications.

Bordetella pertussis (Option D): Bordetella pertussis infection begins with a catarrhal stage marked by mild cough and sneezing, during which the patient is highly contagious. This is followed by a paroxysmal phase characterized by explosive coughing fits with a distinctive"whoop" sound on inhalation, often leading to exhaustion, vomiting, cyanosis, and sometimes convulsions, particularly in infants.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presents with fever and bilateral swelling of sides of face . Which vaccine strain is recommended to prevent this viral infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario suggests a diagnosis of mumps infection and the Jeryl Lynn strain is used in vaccinations used for its prevention.
  • Mumps is a contagious viral illness mainly affecting the salivary glands, particularly the parotids, leading to non-suppurative swelling. While many cases, especially in children under 2 are subclinical, symptomatic individuals often experience glandular pain, fever, and malaise.
  • Mumps virus is a paramyxovirus with negative sense, linear, single-stranded RNA.
  • The infection spreads through respiratory secretions and viremia allows it to affect various organs beyond the salivary glands, including the kidneys, central nervous system, and gonads.
  • The incubation period is typically 14-18 days, and virus shedding in saliva can occur from a few days before to several days after symptoms begin.
  • Neurological involvement is relatively frequent, with aseptic meningitis seen in 10-30% of cases, more in males, and meningoencephalitis may occur even without gland swelling.
  • Though most CNS cases resolve, rare complications like unilateral deafness or encephalitis can occur.
  • In post-pubertal males, 20-50% may develop orchitis, often affecting one testis, leading to pain and occasionally testicular atrophy. Oophoritis and pancreatitis are other complications.
  • Immunity following infection is typically lifelong. Antibodies develop against viral surface proteins, and even asymptomatic infections can generate immune responses.
  • Infants under 6 months rarely get infected due to maternal antibodies. Diagnosis is primarily clinical, with RT-PCR and serology aiding confirmation in atypical cases or when parotitis is absent.
  • There are 12 recognized genotypes of the mumps virus, labeled A through N, excluding E and M. The Jeryl Lynn strain belongs to genotype A.

Explanation of other options:

Oka strain (Option A): The varicella vaccine includes a live, weakened Oka strain of the varicella-zoster virus and is recommended for injection either beneath the skin or into the muscle.

17D strain (Option B): The 17D strain is used in preparations of yellow fever vaccine.

Edmonston Zagreb strain (Option D): It is used in the preparation of measles vaccine.

questions.text: A 3-year old boy presented to Pediatric OPD with complaints of fever and white spots in his mouth, following which he developed rashes behind his ear that spread to his entire body. On taking detailed history, his mother said that she did not vaccinate him as it was against her beliefs. What is the child most likely infected with?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical vignette of fever, white spots in mouth along with rash that spreads from behind the ear to body in an unvaccinated child is suggestive of measles.
  • Measles is a highly contagious viral illness caused by a single-stranded, negative-sense RNA virus of the Paramyxoviridae family, genus Morbillivirus.
  • Measles spreads via respiratory droplets or aerosols, with viral shedding starting 3 days before and lasting up to 4-6 days after rash onset.
  • It infects respiratory epithelial cells, causing inflammation and systemic dissemination. Pathological features include multinucleated giant cells and Warthin-Finkeldey cells as shown below.
  • Measles progresses through incubation, prodromal, exanthem (rash), and recovery phases. The primary viremia spreads to lymph nodes, then disseminates via a secondary viremia.
  • The illness begins with high fever, cough, coryza, and conjunctivitis. Koplik spots as shown below appear inside the cheeks 1-4 days before the rash, which begins on the face and spreads downward.
  • Symptoms peak around rash onset and subside over the next week. Lymphadenopathy and desquamation may occur. In modified measles (e.g., passive immunity or post-vaccination), symptoms may be minimal or absent.
  • Diagnosis is largely clinical. Lab findings in acute illness include decreased white blood cells, particularly lymphocytes. Confirmation is done via detection of IgM antibodies or PCR. A fourfold rise in IgG titers also confirms recent infection.
  • Complications include pneumonia (most common cause of death), encephalitis, otitis media, sinusitis, and tracheitis. Immunocompromised and malnourished individuals face higher risk. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE), a late complication, may develop years after infection and is often fatal.
  • Treatment is supportive. Ribavirin and vitamin A may benefit severe cases, especially in immunocompromised individuals. Vitamin A reduces morbidity and mortality, especially in children with deficiency.
  • Measles is preventable through vaccination. The measles vaccine is given in two doses, one at 9 months and again at 16 - 24 months.
  • An additional MCV dose is advised for infants starting at 6 months in specific circumstances. A few examples include during measles outbreaks as part of intensified efforts or in areas with ongoing high risk of measles among infants under 9 months.
  • When a measles-containing vaccine (MCV) is given before 9 months of age, it should be documented as an extra dose and noted as "MCV-0" in the child's immunization record.
  • These children must still receive MCV1 and MCV2 at the ages specified in the national immunization schedule.

Explanation of other options:

Mumps (Option A): Mumps frequently presents with salivary gland enlargement, particularly of the parotids, in approximately half of symptomatic individuals, although many cases are subclinical. The central nervous system may also be involved, with aseptic meningitis being relatively common and encephalitis occurring less often, often in the absence of parotid gland swelling. In post-pubertal males, orchitis develops in 20-50% of cases and may result in testicular atrophy, whereas complications like oophoritis and pancreatitis are less frequently observed.

Influenza (Option B): Influenza primarily targets the upper respiratory tract and presents abruptly with fever, chills, headache, muscle aches, malaise, and a dry cough, lasting a few days, while the cough and fatigue may persist for weeks. Pneumonia is a serious complication, especially in elderly or chronically ill individuals, and can be due to viral or bacterial coinfections, with bacterial superinfections facilitated by impaired mucosal defenses.

Polio (Option C): Poliovirus infection is frequently subclinical, but in symptomatic cases, it can present as a mild febrile illness or escalate to severe paralysis. The mild form includes fever, drowsiness, gastrointestinal symptoms, and resolves within days. Nonparalytic cases may involve neck and back stiffness, while paralytic forms result in flaccid paralysis from lower motor neuron injury.

questions.text: A 54-year old man presented with features of encephalitis. He bred pigs in his farm and was suspected to have been in contact with an infected pig. His throat & nasal swabs were collected for RT-PCR test of Nipah virus. What is the reservoir for this virus?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The reservoir for nipah virus is fruit bats.
  • Nipah virus, along with Hendra virus, is a zoonotic paramyxovirus under the Henipavirus genus.
  • Fruit bats (flying foxes) are the primary natural hosts for Nipah viruses. Changes in ecology and animal practices are thought to contribute to the emergence of these infections. (Options A, C, and D ruled out)
  • Pigs may act as an intermediate host in the chain of transmission to humans.
  • Although the exact route of transmission from animals to people is unclear, exposure of the respiratory tract to infected material is likely involved.
  • The disease typically begins with symptoms resembling influenza, then advances to encephalitis, often accompanied by respiratory complications, and results in death in approximately 50% of confirmed cases.
  • Due to their high fatality rates, broad host range, and ability to cross species barriers, it is categorized as Biosafety Level 4 agents, and there are currently no licensed vaccines or established treatments available.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents with wheezing, coughing, and difficulty breathing. The parents report that the child has had a runny nose and fever for the past 2 days. On examination, the infant has nasal flaring, tachypnea, and intercostal retractions. Which of the following is the most common organism causing this ?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical features of wheezing, coughing, tachypnea, and intercostal retractions suggests a diagnosis of acute bronchiolitis and the most common organism causing this is respiratory syncytial virus.
  • Acute bronchiolitis refers to the clinical presentation caused by various viral lower respiratory tract infections in infants and very young children, typically presenting with tachypnea, wheezing, crackles, and rhonchi due to inflammation of the small airways.
  • There is no universally agreed diagnostic criterion, and opinions differ on the upper age limit, with some limiting it to children under 1 year and others extending it up to 2 years or more.
  • Pathophysiology involves bronchiolar obstruction by edema, mucus, and cellular debris, increasing airway resistance during both inspiration and expiration, with greater obstruction during expiration leading to wheezing, air trapping, and hyperinflation.
  • Complete obstruction can cause distal air resorption, atelectasis, hypoxemia from ventilation-perfusion mismatch, and hypercapnia in severe cases.
  • Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV) causes over half the cases, with other viruses including human metapneumovirus, rhinovirus, parainfluenza, influenza, coronavirus, bocavirus, and adenovirus. (Option B, C, and D ruled out)
  • Co-infections can occur, though their impact is uncertain, and respiratory viruses may be detected in many asymptomatic infants under 1 year. While viral bronchiolitis can be mistaken for bacterial pneumonia, bacterial superinfection is rare.
  • Risk is higher in males, children exposed to secondhand smoke, those not breastfed, those in crowded homes, infants of mothers who smoked during pregnancy, and those with infected older family members, who may only show mild cold symptoms.

questions.text: A 17-year old boy presented with confusion and disorientation. Her mother recently noticed his reduced attention and poor memory and states that he has always been a "bright student". The patient was not vaccinated as a child and developed measles at age 1. MRI imaging is done and is shown below. Within 3 days of hospital admission, the patient develops unilateral, slow-myoclonic jerks. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical vignette of reduced attention and memory in a patient with childhood history of measles and increased T2 signal in white-matter is suggestive of subacute sclerosing panencephalitis.
  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is a rare, chronic, and progressive demyelinating CNS disease caused by a persistent non-permissive measles virus infection in brain tissue.
  • Patients typically have a history of measles infection before age 2, followed by a latent period of 6-8 years, after which progressive neurologic decline
  • The majority of cases are diagnosed between ages 5 and 15. Early signs include poor school performance, mood or personality changes, without fever or headache.
  • As the condition advances, intellectual deterioration, focal/generalized seizures, myoclonus, ataxia, and visual disturbances occur, and late-stage disease features unresponsiveness, quadriparesis, spasticity, hyperactive reflexes, and extensor plantar responses.
  • MRI may initially appear normal but later shows increased T2 signal in brain and brainstem white matter.
  • EEG starts with nonspecific slowing and later shows a periodic pattern of high-voltage sharp slow waves every 3-8 seconds with flat background periods.
  • CSF is acellular, with normal/mildly elevated protein, markedly high gamma globulin (>20% of CSF protein), and elevated anti-measles antibodies, with oligoclonal bands often detected.
  • Measles virus can be cultured from brain tissue, with antigen identified immunocytochemically and genome detected via in situ hybridization or PCR.

Explanation of other options:

Huntington disease (Option A): Huntington's disease typically begins between 25 and 45 years of age marked by rapid, nonpatterned, semipurposeful, involuntary choreiform movements.

Guillain-Barre syndrome (Option B): Guillain-Barré syndrome typically presents with rapidly progressive weakness developing over hours to a few days, often accompanied by tingling dysesthesias in the extremities. The legs are more commonly affected than the arms, and facial weakness occurs in about half of cases. Lower cranial nerve involvement may lead to bulbar weakness, causing difficulty in managing secretions and maintaining the airway, sometimes mimicking brainstem ischemia.

Substance abuse (Option C): Substance abuse does not explain the myoclonic reflexes and MRI changes.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male trekker presents to the emergency department with symptoms of agitation, confusion, and an inability to swallow water. He reports recent travel where he explored bat caves in a remote area. Given the patient's symptoms and exposure history, what is the characteristic shape of the causative pathogen?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given features of agitation, confusion, and hydrophobia and history of contact with bats suggest a diagnosis of rabies which is caused by a bullet-shaped
  • Rabies is a severe, almost invariably fatal infection of the central nervous system, typically acquired from the bite of a rabid animal.
  • The rabies virus is a rhabdovirus sharing morphologic and biochemical features with vesicular stomatitis virus and other related animal, plant, and insect viruses.
  • These viruses are rod or bullet-shaped and are enveloped with glycoprotein spikes.
  • The genome consists of single-stranded, negative-sense RNA and encodes five proteins, including the envelope glycoprotein.
  • The virus belongs to the family Rhabdoviridae, genus Lyssavirus, and is the most important medically relevant rhabdovirus.
  • Replication begins when the virus binds to cell surface receptors such as the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor via its glycoprotein spikes.
  • It is widely distributed in infected tissues, especially nervous tissue, saliva, urine, lymph, milk, and blood.
  • Certain bats may transmit the virus without symptoms.
  • Pathogenesis begins with viral replication at the inoculation site, followed by spread to the central nervous system and eventually to other organs, especially salivary glands.
  • The incubation period varies depending on host factors, inoculum size, site, and distance to the CNS. It is shorter with facial bites and longer with leg bites.
  • Rabies produces eosinophilic intracytoplasmic inclusions (Negri bodies) as shown below in neurons, especially the hippocampus and cerebellum, though absence does not exclude the diagnosis.
  • Clinically, rabies progresses through three phases. The prodromal phase lasts 2-10 days with nonspecific symptoms such as malaise, anorexia, headache, photophobia, nausea, vomiting, sore throat, and localized sensations at the bite site.
  • The acute neurologic phase (2-7 days) features nervous system dysfunction with agitation, hallucinations, bizarre behavior, generalized sympathetic overactivity (lacrimation, pupillary dilation, salivation, perspiration), and characteristic hydrophobia or aerophobia. This is followed by coma and death, often from cardiorespiratory arrest.

Explanation of other options:

Rod-shaped (Option A): Refers to many bacteria (e.g., Bacillus, Clostridium) and some viruses, but rabies is not described as rod-shaped.

Club-shaped (Option C): Describes Corynebacterium diphtheriae (due to metachromatic granules), not rabies virus.

Oval-shaped (Option D): Seen in some poxviruses (e.g., vaccinia, variola) which are brick/oval-shaped. Not a feature of rabies virus.

choices.text: Don't give anti-rabies vaccine/Immunoglobulins and manage wound locally

questions.text: A 24-year old vet clinic worker comes to the Emergency Department, with a bite mark on his left foot. He complains of being bitten by a rabbit. He has not taken any prophylactic vaccines. How will you manage the patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Rabbit bites do not require anti-rabies vaccine or immunoglobulin and the wound can be managed locally. (Options A, B and C ruled out)
  • Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) for rabies involves both local wound management and the administration of active and passive immunization.
  • Immediate and thorough wound care is vital and can significantly reduce the risk of infection. It should be carried out without delay, even if vaccination is postponed during a 10-day observation period.
  • All bite wounds and scratches must be washed well with soap and water, devitalized tissue removed, tetanus protection provided, and antibiotics given if indicated.
  • If RIG is not available immediately, it must be administered within seven days after the first vaccine dose. After this point, the body will have begun producing its own antibodies, and passive immunization may be detrimental.
  • When possible, the full RIG dose (20 IU/kg) should be infiltrated directly into the wound, with any remaining amount injected intramuscularly at a site distant from the vaccine injection.
  • if the exposure is via a mucous membrane, the total dose should be given intramuscularly.
  • Commercially available RIG is derived from the serum of hyperimmunized human donors, which is generally well tolerated, with adverse effects such as local pain and mild fever occurring infrequently.
  • If human RIG is unavailable, purified equine RIG can be used in the same way at a dose of 40 IU/kg.

choices.text: Hair follicle of nape of neck

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents to the emergency department with agitation, confusion, and difficulty swallowing. He reports having been bitten by a monkey while in a remote area two weeks ago. The patient experiences painful muscle spasms when attempting to drink water. On examination, he shows signs of neurological involvement, including hyperreflexia and agitation. What is the best specimen for antigen detection in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The best specimen for detection of rabies antigen is the hair follicle at the nape of the neck.
  • Once suspected, rabies-specific laboratory tests are necessary for confirmation. Skin biopsy is based on detecting rabies virus antigen in cutaneous nerves at hair follicles and so the specimen is typically obtained from hairy skin at the nape of the neck.
  • Corneal impression smears generally have low yield. Negative tests before death do not rule out rabies, and repeat testing may be needed. (Option A ruled out)
  • In unvaccinated individuals, detecting serum neutralizing antibodies to rabies virus can be diagnostic. However, as the virus infects immunologically privileged neuronal tissues, antibodies may appear late, sometimes not until after symptom onset, and may be absent at death.
  • Detection of such antibodies in CSF supports rabies encephalitis, regardless of immunization status. The absence of antibodies in recovered patients raises doubts about the diagnosis. (Option C ruled out)
  • RT-PCR amplification allows sensitive and specific detection of rabies virus RNA in fresh saliva, skin biopsy specimens, CSF, and brain tissue. (Option D ruled out)
  • Direct fluorescent antibody (DFA) testing uses rabies virus antibodies conjugated to fluorescent dyes to detect viral antigen in tissues with high sensitivity and specificity. This test can be rapidly performed on skin biopsy and brain tissue samples, identifying rabies antigen in cutaneous nerves at the hair follicle base.

questions.text: A 24-year-old visited the ED after he was bitten by a cat at his veterinary centre and on examination it is a category 3 wound. He has already received pre-exposure prophylaxis. What should be the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Only wound management and anti-rabies vaccine is necessary in this case and there is no need for HRIg since has already received pre-exposure prophylaxis.
  • Preexposure rabies prophylaxis is advised for individuals at occupational or recreational risk of rabies exposure, as well as for certain travelers to areas where rabies is endemic.
  • The initial regimen involves three doses of rabies vaccine administered on days 0, 7, and 21 or 28. Serum neutralizing antibody testing can guide the need for future booster doses.
  • If a previously vaccinated person is exposed to rabies, two booster vaccine doses should be given on days 0 and 3, along with essential wound care. (Option A ruled out)
  • RIG should not be given to those who have been previously vaccinated. (Options B and C ruled out)

questions.text: A scientist studying a virus identifies the presence of Negri bodies in infected cells. These inclusion bodies are characteristic of a specific viral infection. The vaccine used against this infection is prepared from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The fixed virus is used in vaccine preparations against rabies.
  • The rabies virus exists in two primary laboratory forms: the "street" virus and the "fixed" virus.
  • Antirabies vaccines are categorized as neural and non-neural.
  • Neural vaccines, derived from nervous tissue of infected animals with fixed virus, have largely been abandoned due to safety concerns and the availability of affordable tissue culture vaccines.
  • Examples include the Semple vaccine, a 5% suspension of sheep brain infected with fixed virus and inactivated with phenol, and the beta-propiolactone (BPL) vaccine, a phenol-free modification that allows smaller doses.
  • Suckling mouse brain vaccines, prepared from newborn animal brains to reduce myelin-associated proteins, have also been used but present practical and neurological risks.
  • Non-neural vaccines include egg-based and tissue culture The duck egg vaccine, made from fixed virus grown in duck eggs and inactivated with beta-propiolactone, was discontinued due to poor immune response.
  • A more potent purified duck egg vaccine was later replaced by tissue culture options. Live attenuated chick embryo vaccines, such as LEP and HEP, are used in animals but not in humans.
  • Tissue culture vaccines, such as the human diploid cell (HDC) vaccine and purified chick embryo cell (PCEC) vaccine, are highly effective and safe, though HDC production costs are high.
  • Other cultured cell lines, like Vero cells, have also been employed. Subunit vaccines containing only the viral surface glycoprotein are under experimental development.
